title: Brain Facts
description: Test your knowledge about the human brain and how it works!

questions.question: Approximately how much does the average adult human brain weigh?
questions.explanation: The average adult human brain weighs about 3 pounds (1.4 kilograms). Despite being only about 2% of body weight, it uses about 20% of the body's energy.

questions.question: What percentage of the brain is made up of water?
questions.explanation: The brain is about 73% water. Even mild dehydration (just 2%) can affect attention, memory, and other cognitive skills.

questions.question: What is the largest part of the human brain called?
questions.explanation: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain, making up about 85% of its total weight. It is responsible for thinking, learning, memory, and voluntary movements.

questions.question: How many main lobes does each hemisphere of the brain have?
questions.explanation: Each hemisphere has 4 main lobes: frontal (reasoning, planning), parietal (sensory processing), temporal (hearing, memory), and occipital (vision).

questions.question: What are the cells in the brain that transmit information called?
questions.explanation: Neurons are the brain's information-transmitting cells. The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons, each connected to thousands of others.

questions.question: Which part of the brain is responsible for balance and coordination?
questions.explanation: The cerebellum, located at the back of the brain, controls balance, coordination, and fine motor skills. It contains about 50% of the brain's neurons despite being only 10% of its volume.

questions.question: What is the term for the brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections?
questions.explanation: Neuroplasticity is the brain's remarkable ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections throughout life. This ability is crucial for learning, memory, and recovery from brain injuries.

questions.question: Approximately how fast can information travel along neurons in the brain?
questions.explanation: Information can travel along neurons at speeds up to 268 mph (431 km/h). The speed varies depending on the type of neuron and whether it has a myelin sheath.

questions.question: What chemical messenger is often called the 'feel-good' neurotransmitter?
questions.explanation: Dopamine is often called the 'feel-good' neurotransmitter because it plays a key role in reward, motivation, and pleasure. It is also important for motor control and focus.

questions.question: Which part of the brain is most associated with forming new long-term memories?
questions.explanation: The hippocampus is crucial for forming new long-term memories and spatial navigation. Damage to this area can result in an inability to form new memories.

questions.question: What is the protective barrier between the bloodstream and the brain called?
questions.explanation: The blood-brain barrier is a highly selective membrane that prevents most substances in the blood from crossing into the brain. It protects the brain from toxins and pathogens.

questions.question: During which stage of sleep does the brain consolidate most memories?
questions.explanation: REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep is when the brain is most active in consolidating memories, especially procedural and emotional memories. Deep sleep also helps with declarative memory consolidation.

questions.question: Approximately how many synaptic connections does the average adult brain have?
questions.explanation: The adult brain has approximately 100 trillion (10^14) synaptic connections. Each neuron can have thousands of connections to other neurons, creating an incredibly complex network.

questions.question: What part of the brain controls the 'fight or flight' response?
questions.explanation: The amygdala is responsible for the fight-or-flight response and processing emotions, particularly fear. It can trigger rapid emotional reactions before the conscious brain has time to process information.

questions.question: What is the fatty substance that insulates nerve fibers and speeds up neural transmission called?
questions.explanation: Myelin is a fatty white substance that forms a sheath around nerve fibers, insulating them and greatly increasing the speed of electrical impulse transmission. Loss of myelin is associated with diseases like multiple sclerosis.
